title: What is Adapt?
body:
To do any job effectively, you need tools that can help you do the work. In construction, you have tools that can help you drive in nails and screws, cut wood, etc.

To create eLearning, you need tools to help you build your course; these are called eLearning Authoring Tools. Many companies offer eLearning Authoring Tools: Adobe has Captivate, eLearning Brothers has Lectora (previously known as SNAP), dominKnow has DominKnow ONE, and other tools are open source, like Adapt.

Some are harder to use and some easier, but all of these eLearning Authoring Tools do the same thing: they make it easy to create eLearning without the need to know any programming.

title: Magazine
body:
A MAGAZINE contains PAGES with ARTICLES,

ARTICLES are divided into SECTIONS with different layouts, 

and each of these SECTIONS contains ELEMENTS.

  • A magazine contains PAGES. Each page (or set of pages) has information on a topic or subject.
  • A page, depending on the size of the magazine, contains one or more ARTICLES.
  • The body of an article consists of a number of SECTIONS with various layouts. For example, the Introduction section covers the width of the entire page. The sections may have visible Subheaders (section title).
  • To make a magazine more interesting and keep the reader's attention, many paragraphs have attention-grabbing pieces called ELEMENTS.

title: Adapt course
body:
An Adapt course has PAGES with ARTICLES,

ARTICLES with BLOCKS and

BLOCKS with interesting COMPONENTS.

  • In Adapt, a course consists of PAGES. Each page represents a new subject, lesson or learning activity.
  • Each page can have as many ARTICLES as needed. These articles can have “Article Titles” and text to explain what is coming. Typically, each article on a page covers the same topic, but may explore different aspects of it.
  • Each article is made up of many BLOCKS (paragraphs). Just like in a magazine, each block highlights a key message. Similar to a paragraph, some of the blocks may have a visible Subheader (block title), and some may not.
  • Every block has one or two "COMPONENTS" (elements). These can be text, graphics, videos, etc., all to ensure that the learner is engaged and attentive.

title: Instructions Sample video - Add Accordion component
instruction: Select the Play button below to start the video and/or select the Transcript button to read the narration.

_transcript.inlineTranscriptBody:
At the component level, you must select the option Add component. A side panel of available Adapt components appears on the right of the screen. 

  • Select or type to search from the list of available components.
  • Select the Accordion component. There are three buttons that will appear: 
    • Add to left 
    • Add full
    • Add to right 
  • Select the button labelled Add full. A full-width Accordion component is added to the page. 

You can now create content for the component: 

  • On the component card, select the gearwheel button labelled Click to edit and choose Edit from the options. This opens the Component Settings menu.
  • In the field labelled Title, enter a new component title.
  • Written content is added to the box labelled Body.
  • Navigate to the Properties section, then to the field labelled Instructions. Instructions must be added to ensure learners navigate the component properly. 
  • Select the button labelled Add. A side panel will appear with options for adding Item content: 
    • Enter a new item title in the field labelled Item title.
    • Add item body content.
    • Once you have added the item title and body content, navigate to and select the button labelled OK. The item is now added to the accordion component. 
  • Repeat these steps to add another item to the component.
  • To add a graphic to the item: 
    • Select the green button labelled Select an Asset. Adapt will navigate to the asset management library where you will choose the appropriate graphic. 
    • Type the word "suitcase" in the search box. A listing of all the “suitcase” graphics currently available in Adapt will be displayed. 
    • Select the asset labelled OHS-suitcase-worker.png. 
    • Select the button labelled Done. 
    • Add an appropriate description of the image in the field labelled Alt.
    • Use the navigation bar to scroll down and select the button labelled OK. 
  • Select the green button labelled Save, located at the top left of the screen in the sidebar.

When you select the Save button, Adapt will automatically save your component title and content, and take you back to the Page Structure menu.

title: Accordion Component
body:
The Accordion Component:

  • Consists of buttons that expand or collapse to reveal or hide the content inside.
  • Can contain images and/or text inside the accordion. ​
  • Each accordion has a title that provides a clue to its content.
  • It can save space on the screen and prevent overwhelming learners with large amounts of text.

Use the accordion component to present learners with a series of headings which, once selected, expand to reveal the associated text.

The maximum recommended number of headings is eight per component.

Let's review some examples of programming an accordion.

title: Graphic Component
body:
In a graphic component, you can display or hide the title, and you may also choose to display some of the text or not. If your image is decorative, do not add an "alt text" to your image.

When adding your image from the Asset Management library, simply select "autofill" to upload the image to both the Large and Small graphic sections. Note that some images in the Asset Management library should not be uploaded in your course, such as images that belong to specific courses.

Additionally:

  • Images are displayed at full width or half width.
  • Images can be uploaded in any size, but 1200 pixels wide is recommended for a full‑size image (1 component) and 600 pixels for a half-size image (2 components side by side).

title: Text Component Description
body:
The text component is a basic component that can show formatted text. However, images cannot be added to a text component. You may also choose to display or hide the component title.

To copy & paste from another source into Adapt, use the paste as plain text icon (clipboard with a letter T) to insert your text.

Rule of thumb, use bold and italized sparingly.

title: Component title
body:
At ESDC, we use Adapt.

Adapt is a free (open-source software) eLearning Authoring Tool. What makes it easy to use is the way it structures a course.

The best analogy for explaining the structure of an Adapt course is a magazine.

A magazine consists of pages with articles, paragraphs, pictures, stand out quotes, etc. Adapt lets you build courses the same way.  

Let’s look at the typical magazine layout and compare it to the Adapt structure.
